verses.text: Then the Pharisees and Sadducees came and, testing Jesus, asked Him to show them a sign from heaven.
verses.comment: The religious leaders seek a miraculous sign as proof, reflecting skepticism and a lack of faith, despite many signs already done.

verses.text: He answered them, "When it is evening, you say, ‘It will be fair weather, for the sky is red.’
verses.comment: Jesus relates their ability to interpret natural signs but implies their spiritual blindness regarding heavenly signs.

verses.text: And in the morning, you say, ‘There will be a storm today, for the sky is red and threatening.’ You know how to interpret the appearance of the sky, but you cannot interpret the signs of the times.
verses.comment: The inability of the religious leaders to see the spiritual meaning of Jesus’ works draws attention to their neglect of prophecy and revelation.

verses.text: An evil and adulterous generation seeks a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of Jonah.” Then He left them and went away.
verses.comment: The 'sign of Jonah' refers to Jesus’ death and resurrection after three days, a prophetic and supernatural sign confirming His divinity. See also Matt. 12:39-40.

verses.text: When the disciples crossed over to the other side, they had forgotten to bring bread.
verses.comment: A mundane detail reveals the disciples' focus on physical needs, setting up a spiritual lesson.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, "Watch out and beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees."
verses.comment: Yeast here symbolizes corrupt teaching and influence; Jesus warns his followers against adopting false doctrines.

verses.text: And they began discussing among themselves, saying, "It is because we did not bring any bread."
verses.comment: The disciples misunderstand Jesus’ warning, focusing on literal bread instead of the spiritual meaning.

verses.text: But Jesus, aware of this, said, "You of little faith, why are you discussing among yourselves that you do not have bread?
verses.comment: Jesus addresses their spiritual immaturity, reminding them to trust in Divine Providence.

verses.text: Don’t you remember the five loaves for the five thousand, and how many baskets you gathered?
verses.comment: Jesus references miracles previously performed, underlining His divine power over creation and provision as God.

verses.text: Or the seven loaves for the four thousand, and how many baskets you gathered?
verses.comment: Jesus reminds them of a second miracle, reinforcing his authority and the sufficiency of his provision.

verses.text: How is it you don’t understand that I was not talking to you about bread? But beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees."
verses.comment: Jesus clarifies that his teaching is spiritual, warning against false and divisive doctrines.

verses.text: Then they understood that He was not telling them to be on guard against yeast in bread, but against the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
verses.comment: Jesus instructs the apostles to discern doctrine carefully, which is foundational for the future unity and authority of the Church.

verses.text: Now when Jesus came into the district of Caesarea Philippi, He asked His disciples, "Who do people say that the Son of Man is?"
verses.comment: ‘Son of Man’ is a clear reference to the prophetic figure of Daniel 7, pointing to Jesus’ divinity and messianic identity.

verses.text: They said, "Some say John the Baptist, others say Elijah, and others Jeremiah or one of the prophets."
verses.comment: Popular expectations reflect Old Testament prophecy and hope for a renewed prophetic voice.

verses.text: He said to them, "But who do you say that I am?"
verses.comment: Jesus’ question prompts a profession of faith, inviting a revelation about His true nature.

verses.text: Simon Peter replied, "You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God."
verses.comment: Peter confesses Jesus as both Christ and divine Son, fulfilling Psalm 2:7 and establishing a clear doctrine of divinity.

verses.text: Jesus answered him, "Blessed are you, Simon son of Jonah, because flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but My Father who is in heaven."
verses.comment: Divine revelation is necessary for true faith; Peter receives his profession from the Father, showing the supernatural nature of apostolic authority.

verses.text: And I tell you, you are Peter, and on this rock I will build My Church, and the gates of Hades will not prevail against it.
verses.comment: Jesus establishes the apostolic foundation of a visible, unified Church, setting Peter as its chief shepherd. Peter’s unique role foreshadows enduring leadership and spiritual authority.

verses.text: I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven; whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven."
verses.comment: ‘Keys’ symbolize governance and authority (Isaiah 22:22), giving Peter a unique ability to bind and loose, a clear sign of spiritual governance entrusted by Christ Himself.

verses.text: Then He ordered His disciples not to tell anyone that He was the Messiah.
verses.comment: Jesus instructs silence until his mission is complete, perhaps to avoid political misunderstanding of his messianic identity.

verses.text: From that time on Jesus began to show His disciples that He must go to Jerusalem, suffer many things from the elders and chief priests and scribes, be killed, and on the third day be raised.
verses.comment: Jesus predicts His Passion and Resurrection, fulfilling the Old Testament prophecies about the suffering Messiah and His victory over death.

verses.text: Then Peter took Him aside and began to rebuke Him, saying, "Far be it from you, Lord! This shall never happen to you."
verses.comment: Peter’s earthly expectation of the Messiah clashes with the divine plan of salvation through suffering.

verses.text: But He turned and said to Peter, "Get behind Me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to Me; for you are not setting your mind on the things of God, but on the things of man."
verses.comment: Peter is rebuked for misunderstanding the will of God; Christ’s authority here is absolute, correcting even the head apostle. The term ‘Satan’ here means ‘adversary’.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to His disciples, "If anyone wants to come after Me, he must deny himself, take up his cross, and follow Me."
verses.comment: True discipleship is marked by self-denial and participation in Christ’s suffering, echoing the spiritual call to sacrificial living.

verses.text: For whoever wants to save his life will lose it; but whoever loses his life for My sake will find it.
verses.comment: Paradoxically, true life is found in surrender to Christ, embodying the principle of resurrection and eternal hope.

verses.text: What will it profit a man if he gains the whole world, but forfeits his soul? Or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?
verses.comment: The eternal destiny of the soul far outweighs worldly gain; echoes the Psalms’ emphasis on the value of redemption.

verses.text: For the Son of Man will come in the glory of His Father with His angels, and then He will reward each one according to what he has done.
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies His return, judgment, and divine authority—showing the necessity of faithful works and cooperation with grace.

verses.text: "Truly I tell you, some standing here will not taste death before they see the Son of Man coming in His kingdom."
verses.comment: This promise refers both to the Transfiguration (foretaste of divine glory) and the Church’s establishment as the visible presence of Christ’s kingdom among men.
